dublinCore.dc:title: 119 HR 5083 IH: To require the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection and the Federal Trade Commission to conduct a study on use of additional key factors in credit scoring models, and for other purposes.
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Fields introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To require the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection and the Federal Trade Commission to conduct a study on use of additional key factors in credit scoring models, and for other purposes.

section.header: Study on use of additional key factors in credit scoring models

subsection.text: Not later than December 31, 2025, the Director of the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection and the Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission shall jointly submit to Congress a report onâ€”

paragraph.text: the use of credit scoring models that include consideration of key factors described in subsection (b); and
how such models affect the ways in which a creditor evaluates the creditworthiness of a consumer.

subsection.text: The key factors described in this subsection are as follows:

paragraph.text: Payment history for installment contracts, such as Buy Now, Pay Later installment contracts.
Electronic benefit transfer system (as defined in section 904(d)(2)(A)(i) of the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693b(d)(2)(A)(i))) transaction records.
Transaction data from depository institution (as defined in section 3(a) of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act (12 U.S.C. 1813(a))) and credit union accounts.
Payroll deposit or data on the frequency with which an employee makes deposits to an account of a consumer.
Public record data relating to property ownership, business licenses, and court filings relating to assets or real property.
The term credit scoring model means a model for developing a credit score (as defined in section 609(f)(2)(A) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. 1681g(f)(2)(A))).
The term key factor has the meaning given in section 609(f)(2)(B) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. 1681g(f)(2)(B)).
